content_blocks.text: Cloud computing is a way to rent computing over a network instead of owning it. A provider runs the datacenters and you consume compute, storage, and networking on demand.

A key idea is *resource pooling*: many customers share a large pool of hardware. That shared-customer model is called *multitenancy*. Good cloud design isolates tenants so one customer can’t see another’s data.

checks.prompt: Which statement best captures the core idea of cloud computing?
options: Renting computing resources over a network from a provider
Buying servers and placing them in a provider’s building
Using only thin clients instead of PCs
Running everything on a single mainframe
checks.explanation: Cloud computing is primarily about on‑demand consumption of provider-hosted resources over a network.

checks.prompt: In a multitenant cloud, what is being shared?
options: A pool of physical infrastructure used by multiple customers
Only the operating system installed on your VM
Your encryption keys with other organizations
Your administrative accounts with other customers
checks.explanation: Multitenancy means multiple customers run workloads on shared underlying hardware with isolation between them.

content_blocks.text: Cloud services are designed to be: on‑demand (self‑service), reachable over the network, and measured (you’re billed by usage).
Two closely related terms: *scalability* is the ability to grow capacity; *elasticity* is scaling up and down automatically to match demand and cost.
Scaling can be vertical (bigger server) or horizontal (more servers). Horizontal scaling is often the cloud’s superpower.

checks.prompt: What’s the best one-line difference between scalability and elasticity?
options: Scalability grows capacity; elasticity grows and shrinks capacity as demand changes
Scalability is only horizontal; elasticity is only vertical
Elasticity is manual; scalability is automatic
They are identical terms on the exam
checks.explanation: Scalability focuses on growth; elasticity adds the idea of contraction when demand drops.

checks.prompt: Horizontal scaling usually means…
options: Adding more servers/instances to share the load
Adding more RAM to an existing server
Switching to a faster CPU in the same machine
checks.explanation: Horizontal scaling increases capacity by adding instances, not upgrading a single machine.

content_blocks.text: Cloud environments involve multiple roles. The *cloud service provider (CSP)* runs the infrastructure and delivers services.
The *consumer* uses those services. A *broker* helps consumers pick/manage services. A *carrier* provides the network path. An *auditor* independently evaluates security and compliance.

checks.prompt: Which cloud role is responsible for delivering the cloud service?
checks.explanation: The provider operates the datacenters and delivers the service.

checks.prompt: Which role independently assesses security or compliance?
checks.explanation: Auditors perform independent evaluation/assurance.

pages.title: Service models: IaaS vs PaaS vs SaaS vs FaaS

content_blocks.text: Service models describe *how much the provider manages* for you.
*IaaS*: you rent virtual servers, storage, and networking. You secure the OS and anything above it.
*PaaS*: the provider also manages the OS/runtime platform; you focus on your code and data.
*SaaS*: you use a complete application; you mainly control your data and app configuration.
*FaaS / serverless*: you upload small functions; execution infrastructure is hidden from you.

checks.prompt: In which model do customers typically manage the guest OS security patches?
checks.explanation: In IaaS, the customer is responsible for the guest OS and above.

checks.prompt: Which model is most accurately described as 'serverless'?
checks.explanation: FaaS is commonly called serverless because the server layer is abstracted away from customers.

modules.title: Cloud deployment models and hybrid considerations

pages.title: Deployment models: public, private, community, hybrid

content_blocks.text: *Public cloud*: multitenant infrastructure open to many customers.
*Private cloud*: cloud infrastructure for a single customer (may be on‑prem or hosted).
*Community cloud*: shared by organizations with common needs (e.g., sector/regulatory).
*Hybrid cloud*: connects two or more clouds/on‑prem environments into one operating model.

checks.prompt: Which deployment model is *dedicated to one customer*?
checks.explanation: Private clouds are provisioned for a single customer.

checks.prompt: Which model requires a unifying approach to tie multiple environments together?
checks.explanation: Hybrid combines multiple environments into one operational approach.

content_blocks.text: *Cloud bursting* is a hybrid strategy: run mostly in a private environment, but use public cloud capacity when demand spikes.
Hybrid and multicloud can also reduce single points of failure by moving from a centralized architecture to a more decentralized one—at the cost of more complexity.

checks.prompt: Cloud bursting is best described as…
options: Using public cloud to handle overflow demand beyond private capacity
Running only edge devices with no cloud
checks.explanation: Bursting means temporarily using public cloud resources when demand exceeds private capacity.

checks.prompt: A key security tradeoff of decentralizing across providers is…
options: Reduced single points of failure but higher management complexity
Guaranteed lower costs with no downside
checks.explanation: Decentralization can improve resilience but usually increases operational complexity.

modules.title: Shared responsibility model and responsibility matrix

pages.title: Shared responsibility: the core cloud security idea

content_blocks.text: Cloud security is a division of labor. Providers always handle physical datacenter + hardware security.
Responsibility shifts higher in the stack depending on IaaS/PaaS/SaaS. In IaaS you own OS/app security; in SaaS the provider owns most operational security.
Treat this as a *responsibility matrix*: explicitly document who does what.

checks.prompt: Which layer is *always* the cloud provider’s responsibility in valid cloud services?
checks.explanation: If the customer runs the datacenter/hardware, it’s not cloud in the usual definition.

checks.prompt: In general, which model places the most operational security burden on the provider?
checks.explanation: SaaS providers manage the application stack; customers mainly manage data use and access configuration.

pages.title: Responsibility matrix: don’t guess—write it down

content_blocks.text: Compliance and audits get messy if responsibilities are vague. Write down who patches what, who monitors what, who responds to incidents, and how evidence is collected.
Cloud contracts should clarify audit rights and expectations, especially when third parties are involved.

checks.prompt: Why is documenting a responsibility matrix especially important?
options: It reduces gaps during compliance and incident response
It eliminates the need for encryption
checks.explanation: A written matrix prevents 'we thought you handled it' failures.

checks.prompt: Which contract item best supports security governance in the cloud?
options: A promise that breaches never happen
checks.explanation: Audit rights and evidence access are key governance items.

modules.title: Cloud governance frameworks (NIST/CSA) and vendor oversight

content_blocks.text: Cloud has standards and reference docs to keep you sane. NIST SP 500‑292 provides a cloud reference architecture to describe components and relationships.
The Cloud Security Alliance (CSA) publishes the Cloud Controls Matrix (CCM), a control catalog that helps map cloud controls to common compliance frameworks.

checks.prompt: Which document helps map cloud security controls to many regulatory standards?
checks.explanation: CSA CCM is designed for control mapping across standards.

checks.prompt: NIST SP 500-292 is best described as…
checks.explanation: It provides a reference architecture for cloud computing.

content_blocks.text: Cloud environments usually mean third‑party vendors. Governance includes vetting vendors, monitoring stability, and managing your cloud portfolio.
Auditability matters: contracts should address reporting, evidence access, and how you validate provider controls (including third‑party controls).

checks.prompt: Cloud governance primarily helps organizations…
options: Select, manage, and monitor cloud vendor relationships
Replace all security controls with CASB
Eliminate the need for incident response
checks.explanation: Governance guides vendor selection and ongoing oversight.

checks.prompt: Auditability is best supported by…
options: Contract terms granting audit rights and evidence access
checks.explanation: You need contractual and technical mechanisms to obtain assurance evidence.

modules.title: Edge and fog computing (concept + security impact)

pages.title: Edge and fog computing: when cloud is too far away

content_blocks.text: Sometimes sensors are remote or links are unreliable. Sending raw data back to the cloud can be slow or impossible.
*Edge computing* pushes some processing to devices at the network edge. *Fog computing* uses nearby gateways to preprocess/aggregate before sending data onward.

checks.prompt: Edge computing primarily exists to…
options: Process data closer to the source when connectivity/latency is a problem
checks.explanation: Edge/fog approaches reduce bandwidth and latency by processing near sensors.

checks.prompt: Fog computing commonly relies on…
checks.explanation: Fog uses nearby gateway devices as intermediate compute nodes.

content_blocks.text: More locations = more attack surface: physical tampering, weak patching, and exposed interfaces.
Treat edge nodes like production systems: strong IAM, secure updates, encryption, logging, and segmentation back to core services.

checks.prompt: A key security challenge introduced by edge/fog is…
options: Expanded attack surface across many distributed devices
Guaranteed lower risk than centralized cloud
checks.explanation: Distributed devices are harder to patch, monitor, and physically protect.

checks.prompt: Which control most directly helps limit damage if an edge node is compromised?
checks.explanation: Segmentation limits lateral movement from compromised edge systems.

content_blocks.text: Virtualization lets one physical host run multiple virtual machines (VMs). The hypervisor provides each VM the illusion of a separate computer and enforces isolation.
Isolation matters operationally (VMs shouldn’t interfere) and for security (one VM shouldn’t access another’s memory/disk).

checks.prompt: What component enforces isolation between virtual machines?
checks.explanation: The hypervisor controls resource access and isolation between VMs.

checks.prompt: Virtualization is best described as…
options: Running multiple virtual systems on shared physical hardware
Only using containers with no OS
A way to encrypt all data automatically
checks.explanation: Virtualization is the abstraction of physical resources to host multiple virtual machines.

pages.title: Type I vs Type II hypervisors

content_blocks.text: *Type I (bare‑metal)* hypervisors run directly on hardware and host guest OSes—common in datacenters.
*Type II* hypervisors run on top of a host OS—common on desktops/laptops for dev/test, but usually less efficient.

checks.prompt: Which hypervisor type is most common in datacenter virtualization?
checks.explanation: Type I hypervisors are designed for datacenter efficiency and scale.

checks.prompt: A Type II hypervisor runs…
options: On top of a host operating system
Directly on hardware with no OS
checks.explanation: Type II hypervisors are hosted by a conventional OS.

modules.title: Virtualization security: VM escape, sprawl, resource reuse

content_blocks.text: A VM escape occurs when an attacker in one VM breaks out of isolation and reaches the host or other VMs.
This is why hypervisor hardening, patching, and strict separation of security zones matter in virtualized environments.

checks.prompt: VM escape means…
options: A process in a VM breaks isolation and accesses host/other VMs
A container image is too large
checks.explanation: Escape attacks violate the hypervisor isolation boundary.

checks.prompt: What is primarily responsible for preventing VM escape attacks?
checks.explanation: The hypervisor boundary is what escape attacks attempt to break.

content_blocks.text: *VM sprawl* happens when teams create instances and forget them—costs rise and unpatched systems accumulate.
*Resource reuse* is a provider risk: hardware reassigned between customers must be properly wiped or the next tenant might see leftovers.
Good hygiene: asset inventory, deprovisioning workflows, patch management, and secure wiping/crypto erasure.

checks.prompt: VM sprawl most directly increases risk by…
options: Leaving unmanaged/forgotten instances unpatched over time
checks.explanation: Forgotten instances become vulnerable and are often missed by scans/patch cycles.

checks.prompt: Resource reuse risk occurs when…
options: Hardware is reassigned and data remnants aren’t removed
checks.explanation: If data is not properly removed before reassignment, another tenant may see remnants.

content_blocks.text: Containers package an application and its dependencies, but they share the host kernel. They’re lighter than VMs, but isolation is different and must be enforced carefully.
Think of containers as 'application isolation' while VMs are closer to 'machine isolation'.

checks.prompt: Containers primarily provide…
checks.explanation: Containers virtualize at the application level, sharing the host kernel.

checks.prompt: A major security consideration of containers is…
options: Enforcing isolation since the kernel is shared
checks.explanation: Shared-kernel designs require careful isolation and hardening.

content_blocks.text: Hardening tactics include using minimal container host OSes, segmenting containers by risk/purpose, and using container-focused vulnerability tools.
Rule of thumb: treat containers like VMs—patch, monitor, restrict access, and limit what they can reach.

checks.prompt: Which is a reasonable container-hardening recommendation?
options: Use minimal container host OS and segment containers by risk
Run all containers as root with full network access
Disable vulnerability scanning to reduce noise
checks.explanation: Reducing attack surface and segmenting by risk are standard hardening moves.

checks.prompt: Why is 'treat containers like VMs' good advice?
options: They still run code and can be attacked; you must patch/monitor/isolate them
Containers are always more secure than VMs
checks.explanation: Containers are still compute workloads and must be secured.

pages.title: Block vs object storage (and why you care)

content_blocks.text: Cloud storage commonly comes as *block storage* (virtual disks attached to VMs) and *object storage* (files stored as objects in buckets via web/API).
Block is usually preallocated (you pay for allocated size). Object is usually pay-for-what-you-use and often cheaper.

checks.prompt: Which storage type is commonly accessed as objects in buckets via API/web?
checks.explanation: Object storage stores independent objects in buckets.

checks.prompt: A typical billing difference is…
options: Block storage is often billed for allocated capacity; object storage for used capacity
Object storage is always billed per allocated TB
They are billed identically in all providers
checks.explanation: Block is often preallocated; object is more consumption-based.

content_blocks.text: Three big cloud storage security moves: (1) set permissions carefully (especially buckets), (2) plan for durability/availability with replication, and (3) encrypt sensitive data (file-level or disk-level).
Misconfigured object storage permissions are a classic real-world breach pattern.

checks.prompt: The most common cloud storage “oops” that causes data exposure is…
checks.explanation: Permissions mistakes (especially in object storage) frequently lead to unintended public exposure.

checks.prompt: Which control best protects confidentiality of sensitive cloud data at rest?
checks.explanation: Encryption protects data at rest (when implemented and keyed properly).

modules.title: Cloud networking security: security groups and VPCs

pages.title: Cloud networking: SDN/SDV and security groups

content_blocks.text: Cloud networking is software-defined: you create and modify networks through APIs (SDN). Visibility into virtual traffic is also software-defined (SDV).
Security groups are provider-managed firewall-like rules applied to cloud resources. They commonly operate at the network layer, like a traditional firewall.
Providers may also offer WAFs (web application firewalls) at higher layers for HTTP(S) traffic.

checks.prompt: Security groups function most similarly to…
checks.explanation: Security groups implement firewall-style rules at the network layer.

checks.prompt: A WAF is most associated with protecting…
checks.explanation: WAFs inspect web application traffic at higher OSI layers.

content_blocks.text: A Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) lets you segment cloud networks into subnets, similar to on-prem segmentation.
Segmentation isolates systems of different trust levels. Combine VPC/subnets with security groups to limit lateral movement.
Secure web gateways (SWGs) and other controls may be used to manage user access to external web resources.

checks.prompt: A VPC is primarily used to…
options: Create segmented virtual networks in the cloud
checks.explanation: VPCs provide a virtual network boundary and segmentation tools.

checks.prompt: Segmentation primarily helps by…
options: Limiting communication between systems of different security levels
checks.explanation: Segmentation reduces blast radius and limits lateral movement.

modules.title: DevOps automation: IaC, microservices, serverless, secrets

content_blocks.text: DevOps reduces hand-offs by combining development and operations with automation. Faster delivery requires stronger automation guardrails.

Infrastructure as Code (IaC) means describing infrastructure in files (often JSON/YAML) or code that calls cloud APIs. It improves repeatability, but mistakes can replicate fast—so reviews and validation are critical.

checks.prompt: Which is NOT an example of infrastructure as code?
options: Using a web UI to manually provision resources
Writing code that calls a cloud provider API
checks.explanation: IaC is about defining/provisioning through code/config files, not manual clicking.

checks.prompt: A major benefit of IaC is…
options: Eliminating the need for security groups
checks.explanation: IaC makes deployments consistent and repeatable when implemented with good controls.

content_blocks.text: Microservices split an app into small services that communicate (often via APIs/events). Serverless/FaaS is a common execution model for microservices.
APIs become a major attack surface: authenticate, authorize, validate inputs, and log. Protect keys and tokens using secrets management.
HSMs can generate/manage cryptographic keys without exposing them to humans, offering strong key protection when configured correctly.

checks.prompt: Microservices architectures often increase the importance of…
checks.explanation: Microservices rely on APIs/events, making API security critical.

checks.prompt: An HSM is best described as…
options: A device/service for secure key management and cryptographic operations
A web proxy for filtering URLs
checks.explanation: HSMs manage keys and perform crypto operations securely.

modules.title: Cloud security issues and controls: sovereignty, CASB, monitoring

pages.title: Cloud security issues: availability + data sovereignty

content_blocks.text: Cloud gives geographic diversity, but high availability isn’t always automatic—you may need to configure or purchase HA options.
Data sovereignty means data stored/processed in other jurisdictions may be subject to those countries’ laws. Many providers let you choose regions to control where data lives.

checks.prompt: Why can cloud services still require explicit high availability configuration?
options: Base services may not include HA by default
checks.explanation: Cloud often offers HA options, but you must select/configure them.

checks.prompt: Data sovereignty concerns arise because…
options: Data may be stored/processed in jurisdictions with different laws
Encryption is not allowed in the cloud
checks.explanation: Cross-border storage/processing can trigger legal and regulatory obligations.

content_blocks.text: CASBs (Cloud Access Security Brokers) sit between users and cloud services to enforce policies and monitor activity.
Two common approaches: inline CASB (traffic flows through it) and API-based CASB (talks to providers via APIs).
Cloud misconfigurations are a top risk. Strong logging/monitoring helps detect drift, abuse, and policy violations early.

checks.prompt: A CASB primarily helps organizations…
options: Enforce policies consistently across many cloud services
checks.explanation: CASBs are policy enforcement/visibility tools between users and cloud services.

checks.prompt: If you want a CASB approach that interacts with providers directly, choose…
checks.explanation: API-based CASBs integrate with providers via APIs rather than inline traffic routing.
